response.answer_text: Wow. That’s a term that evokes the ‘90’s and CD-ROMS! I didn’t think anyone actually used those terms any more. Perhaps you’re talking about a course like this? Multimedia Computing BSc (Hons) | 2016/17 | Covent... In the olden days, computers were accessed via a terminal, like this (DEC VT-100):  See the screen? That’s just plain text. When you said “computer” in those days, you meant text. Then, the GUI came out:  Notice that this is a Xerox machine. They invented the GUI at PARC (no, Apple did not invent the GUI). Look at the screen, PICTURES! Wow! Then, we got video and audio. Each one of these is a different type of Media. Thus, you have multiple types of media on one system. Or, in other words MULTIMEDIA. Like this:  Nowadays, we just call this “the web” and move on.

Multimedia Computing is a course that encompasses the technologies behind the creative industry, which is one of the fastest growing industries the UK. We focus on developing student skills for a career in web and smartphone development, audio/visual creation as well as 2D/3D graphics and animation.
